Teaser: The study isn't a substitute for a bona fide prospective randomized trial, but it is large and controlled for a lot of potential confounders. Why its conclusions contrast with those of some prior studies isn't known for sure, but there's at least one good possible reason.

Headlines: Acyclovir, Valacyclovir in First Trimester Not Linked to Major Birth Defects
Teaser: In a large nationwide cohort, use of acyclovir or valacyclovir in the first trimester of pregnancy was not associated with an increased risk for major birth defects.

Headlines: EEG Testing May Predict Clozapine Response in Treatment-Resistant Schizophrenia
Teaser: A new pilot study suggests that EEG testing can predict whether patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia will respond to clozapine, a drug known for its potentially serious adverse effects.

Headlines: Withdrawal of Midodrine
Teaser: The FDA is recommending the withdrawal of midodrine hydrochloride, currently used in the treatment of hypotension, because there are insufficient data to support its benefit.

Headlines: Nebulized 3% Saline Without Bronchodilators May Be Safe for Bronchiolitis
Teaser: In a retrospective cohort, nebulized 3% saline solution without adjunctive bronchodilators for inpatients with bronchiolitis had a low rate of adverse events.

Headlines: Truncated Rimonabant Study Published
Teaser: Truncated results from rimonabant's large morbidity and mortality study, a report that editorialists call "the obituary for a wonder drug," are reported this week. The CRESCENDO investigators, however, did not want the trial stopped, but a decision by the EMA tied their clinical hands.

Headlines: Acetaminophen Use in Adolescents May Double Risk for Asthma
Teaser: A global study shows that acetaminophen use in adolescents is linked to the development and/or maintenance of asthma, rhinoconjunctivitis, and eczema.

Headlines: FDA Warns of Aseptic Meningitis Risk With Lamotrigine
Teaser: FDA is warning that lamotrigine (Lamictal, GlaxoSmithKline), approved for treatment of epilepsy and bipolar disorder, can cause aseptic meningitis.

Headlines: Multiple Courses of Antenatal Corticosteroids May Not Improve Outcomes
Teaser: Multiple courses of prenatal corticosteroids every 14 days did not increase or decrease the risk for death or neurologic impairment at ages 18 to 24 months vs a single course.

Headlines: FDA Warns Against Over-the-Counter Chelation Treatments
Teaser: All over-the-counter chelation treatments are illegal, says the FDA.

Headlines: FDA Panel to Review Darbepoetin
Teaser: An early safety review posted online questions the treatment strategy in light of the absence of benefit and increased risk of stroke observed in the TREAT study.

Headlines: More Heparin Trouble for SPL
Teaser: Scientific Protein Laboratories has been reprimanded by the US FDA for failing to investigate a complaint about contaminated heparin months after the heparin recalls in 2008.

Headlines: FDA Adds Femur Fracture Warning to Bisphosphonate Labels
Teaser: The label change applies only to bisphosphonates approved for the treatment of osteoporosis.

Headlines: Atorvastatin Recall
Teaser: Pfizer has recalled seven lots of atorvastatin (Lipitor) because of an "uncharacteristic odor related to the bottles in which the product is packaged".

Headlines: Abbott Withdraws Sibutramine From Market
Teaser: The US FDA asked the manufacturer to pull the weight-loss medication from the market after clinical trial data pointed to a 16% increase in the risk for serious cardiovascular events.

Headlines: COGENT Published
Teaser: Patients on dual antiplatelet therapy had a significant reduction in GI events with omeprazole and no increase in cardiovascular events in the first randomized trial of PPI use with clopidogrel. And a new mechanistic study suggests that the clopidogrel-omeprazole interaction may be dose dependent.

Headlines: New Discipline of Cardioncology Evolves as Cancer Patients Live Longer
Teaser: Growing awareness about the cardiovascular adverse effects of novel anticancer drugs has given birth to a new discipline of cardioncology.

Headlines: FDA Deputy on Rosiglitazone
Teaser: Dr Joshua Sharfstein, principal deputy commissioner of the FDA, discusses the recent FDA decision to allow Avandia to stay on the market with restricted access and compares the decision with the European approach that suspended the drug.

Headlines: Caffeine Intake During Pregnancy Not Linked to Risk for Preterm Birth
Teaser: A meta-analysis of cohort and case-control studies shows no important association between caffeine intake during pregnancy and the risk for preterm birth.

Headlines: Medications for Insomnia or Anxiety Linked to 36% Increase in Mortality Risk
Teaser: Because sedative drug use is associated with a 36% increase in mortality risk, physicians should consider nonpharmacologic treatment options for insomnia or anxiety.

Headlines: Lots of Epogen and Procrit Recalled Due to Glass Flakes in Vials
Teaser: Several lots epoetin alfa vials are subject to recall, according to an FDA alert.

Headlines: PPIs After MI Linked to Increased Risk for Adverse Cardiovascular Outcomes
Teaser: Proton pump inhibitors are associated with an increased risk for adverse cardiovascular outcomes after discharge in patients with myocardial infarction, regardless of clopidogrel use.

Headlines: Reaction to Rosiglitazone Decisions Mixed, But Measured
Teaser: Diabetes doctors convened at the EASD meeting in Stockholm have given their verdict on the differing decisions made by the European and American regulatory authorities yesterday on the fate of rosiglitazone. In the US, Nissen says he is "pleased" by the EMA actions; the FDA moves are "reasonable," he added.

Headlines: FDA Restricts Rosiglitazone, But EMA Suspends It
Teaser: After months of deliberations, the FDA has opted to allow Avandia to stay on the market, but only with severe restrictions. It also opted to stop the TIDE trial, pending a rereview of the RECORD trial.  In contrast, the EMA has ordered the suspension of all rosiglitazone-containing products

Headlines: Clopidogrel-PPI: Mechanistic Studies
Teaser: But cardiologists continue to debate whether these results, which show a definite interaction, are clinically relevant.

Headlines: FDA Studying Possible Link Between Pioglitazone and Bladder Cancer
Teaser: Study of 193,000 Kaiser patients shows increased risk after 24 months of treatment, but the agency has not reached any conclusions about causation.

Headlines: Sibutramine Risks Warrant Restrictions or Withdrawal: FDA Panel
Teaser: Six members of the FDA panel voted to recommend that the FDA severely restrict access to the weight-loss drug, and eight recommended the plug be pulled on it altogether. Only two on the panel reviewing the SCOUT trial concluded that the drug should remain on the market with a boxed warning only, and no members thought the drug could stay with no labeling changes.

Headlines: Hormonal Analog Reduces Visceral Adipose Tissue in HIV-Infected Patients
Teaser: A pooled analysis of 2 phase 3 trials shows benefits of tesamorelin across subgroups of HIV-positive patients, including sex, race, and varying disease characteristics.

Headlines: Benfluorex, Hospitalizations, Deaths, Valvular Disease
Teaser: The drug, available in just a handful of countries, is also used off-label to treat obesity. A new report links it to at least 500 deaths and at least 3500 hospitalizations in France.

Headlines: APPRAISE-2 Halted
Teaser: The move will include all propoxyphene-containing products, both brand-name and generic.

Headlines: Propoxyphene Withdrawn From US Market
Teaser: This brings the total number of cases to 75.

Headlines: Biogen Reports 5 New Cases of PML With Natalizumab
Teaser: Looking back, historians may mark 2010 as the most significant year for US medicine in decades.

Headlines: Top 10 Medical News Stories of 2010
Teaser: The US Department of Health and Human Services Office of Inspector General recommends that the Medicare program expand the list of adverse events for which it will not foot the bill.

Headlines: Nearly 1 in 7 Hospitalized Medicare Patients Experience Adverse Events
Teaser: In a study of healthy older men, dihydrotestosterone treatment for 24 months did not affect prostate growth but caused a decrease in spinal, but not hip, bone mineral density.

Headlines: Dihydrotestosterone May Not Affect Prostate Growth But May Reduce BMD
Teaser: Children are more likely than adults to be positive to amoxicillin on penicillin skin testing.

Headlines: Kids More Likely to Show Allergy to Amoxicillin Than Adults
Teaser: Studies comparing topical and oral diclofenac for the treatment of knee osteoarthritis showed comparable efficacy and fewer adverse effects with the topical formulation.

Headlines: Topical vs Oral Diclofenac: Equal Efficacy, Fewer Adverse Effects
Teaser: Aromatase inhibitors are powerful medicine for postmenopausal women with breast cancer, but they also have a lot of adverse effects.

Headlines: Aromatase Inhibitor Adverse Effects Are Like "Menopause Plus"
Teaser: A quarterly publication from the nonprofit Institute for Safe Medicine Practices has aired safety issues with Multaq, approved recently for atrial fibrillation, and questions its "suitability for widespread use."

Headlines: ISMP Report Questions Multaq Safety
Teaser: The document recommends the use of proton-pump inhibitors in patients taking thienopyridine antiplatelet agents at high risk of GI bleeding but not in those at low risk; exactly how to define high- and low-risk patients is left to the individual physician.

Headlines: PPIs and Antiplatelets: Consensus
Teaser: A joint panel of FDA experts has voted unanimously in favor of keeping intravenous phenytoin on the market, despite known serious adverse effects, such as purple glove syndrome.

Headlines: Phenytoin Injection Should Stay on the Market, FDA Panels Recommend
Teaser: A new meta-analysis shows that the incidence of cough occurring with ACE inhibitors is almost 10-fold higher than is stated in the drugs' labels or in the Physicians' Desk Reference. The findings are cause for concern, given that this underreporting could also be happening with more severe side effects, say the researchers; they call for the updating of drug labels to become mandatory.

Headlines: Nuisance Side-Effect Underreported in Label; Implications Are Important
Teaser: A California heparin manufacturer, supplied by a company that played a role in the worldwide 2008 heparin recall, has announced a new recall that so far involves only seven lots of the product.

Headlines: SPL, B Braun Medical in New Heparin Recall
Teaser: The MedWatch drug safety surveillance program is passive and reactive, underutilized, and does not contain enough detail; FDA's Surveillance Initiative is intended to correct this.

Headlines: Drug Safety Surveillance
Teaser: The contaminated antimetabolite could trigger a variety of serious adverse events, depending on the kind of parenteral administration.

Headlines: Sandoz Recalls Methotrexate Vials That May Contain Glass Flakes
Teaser: Eighteen lots of fentanyl transdermal 25 mcg/hour patches are subject to voluntary recall because of the accelerated release of fentanyl in 1 patch.

Headlines: Fentanyl Transdermal System Lots Recalled
Teaser: The FDA is advising clinicians to perform an electrocradiogram before starting patients on saquinavir combined with ritonavir.

Headlines: New Warning of Cardiac Risk Added to Saquinavir Label
Teaser: Patients receiving GnRH agonists may be at a "small increased risk" for diabetes, heart attack, stroke, and sudden death.

Headlines: Humanized Monoclonal Antibody May Be Effective, Safe in Asthma Patients
Teaser: In a systematic review, add-on therapy with a subcutaneous humanized monoclonal antibody was safe and effective in patients with moderate to severe allergic asthma.

Headlines: Fatal Medication Errors Seen With High-Dose Morphine Oral Solution
Teaser: Due to reports of serious adverse events and deaths, labeling and packaging for high-potency morphine sulfate oral solution have been revised.

Headlines: First-in-Class Antibiotic Has High Risk of Adverse Events and Death
Teaser: Despite the similar efficacy with comparator drugs, tigecycline was associated with an increased incidence of all adverse events, especially those involving the digestive system.

Headlines: Bevacizumab Increases Heart Failure in Patients With Breast Cancer
Teaser: Yet another adverse effect has been reported for bevacizumab in the treatment of advanced breast cancer -- congestive heart failure.

Headlines: Complementary, Alternative Medicine Linked to Adverse Events in Children
Teaser: A surveillance study shows that complementary and alternative medicine, especially when associated with failure to use conventional medicine, can lead to serious and fatal adverse events in children.

Headlines: FDA Warns of Possible Increased Risk for Death With Somatropin
Teaser: A long-term follow-up study from France hints at a possible increased risk for death in people treated with the recombinant human growth hormone somatropin during childhood.

Headlines: FDA Targets Tainted Dietary Supplements
Teaser: The FDA warns supplement industry and launches a new system to notify consumers.

Headlines: FDA Warns Against Injection Dolasetron Due to Risk for Heart Arrhythmias
Teaser: Because of heart rhythm abnormalities, the FDA recommends no longer using the injectable form of dolasetron mesylate for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Headlines: Candy-Like Cough Capsules May Pose Serious Risk to Young Children
Teaser: The FDA reports 7 cases of accidental ingestion associated with benzonatate (Tessalon) in children younger than 10 years.

Headlines: Rofecoxib Risks Confirmed to Last at Least a Year After Discontinuation
Teaser: A new analysis of the only other study known to have continued to follow outcomes in patients once they had stopped taking the COX-2 inhibitor rofecoxib confirms that a doubling of cardiovascular risk persisted in those who took the drug for at least a year after stopping therapy.

Headlines: Stopping CRESCENDO Early
Teaser: One group argues that the trial was stopped too late, noting that the adverse psychiatric profile of the drug was raised as early as 2006, months before CRESCENDO even began, while another researcher wonders whether or not genetic testing might have identified patients taking rimonabant who were at risk for suicide.

Headlines: Pfizer Pulls PAH Drug Due to Liver Toxicity
Teaser: Pfizer announced today that it will voluntarily withdraw sitaxentan, a drug for pulmonary arterial hypertension, following two cases of fatal liver toxicity.

Headlines: Osteoporosis Risk With Asthma and COPD Therapies Needs More Vigilance
Teaser: For patients with asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who are taking therapies that pose a risk for osteoporosis, screening might help prevent irreversible bone loss.

Headlines: FDA Advisors Mostly Positive on Naltrexone/Bupropion Diet Drug
Teaser: In all, 13 panel members voted "yes" to the question of whether the potential benefits of naltrexone/bupropion outweigh its potential risks if used long term, while seven voted "no." On a separate question, eight voted to recommend that a cardiovascular outcomes study be conducted prior to drug approval, while 11 voted that such a study could happen postapproval.

Headlines: Escalated BEACOPP Superior to ABDV in Early Hodgkin's Lymphoma
Teaser: The more aggressive chemotherapy regimen gave better overall tumor control, but at the cost of greater toxicity and no survival difference.

Headlines: Invisalign 'Invisible Braces' Maker Gets FDA Warning
Teaser: Adverse events were not reported to the agency, the FDA says.

Headlines: New Review Reassures on ARB/Cancer Risk, But Questions Linger
Teaser: A new meta-analysis has found no increased risk of cancer or cancer death with any antihypertensive drug, including angiotensin receptor blockers, countering the conclusions of another review published earlier this year. However, the new paper did find an increased cancer risk with the combination of ARB plus ACE inhibitor, so questions still remain. Regulatory agencies are currently reviewing the

Headlines: Therapeutic Acetaminophen Not Linked to Liver Injury in Children
Teaser: A systematic review shows that hepatoxicity after therapeutic dosing of acetaminophen in children is rarely reported in defined-population studies.

Headlines: First-Trimester PPI Use May Not Significantly Increase Risk for Birth Defects
Teaser: In a large cohort, exposure to proton-pump inhibitors during the month before conception, but not during the first trimester, was associated with a significantly increased risk for major birth defects.

Headlines: Grass Allergy Immunotherapy Tablet Shows Promise for Children
Teaser: A grass allergy immunotherapy tablet is effective and safe in children 5 years and older.

Headlines: Hydrocodone Bitartrate/Acetaminophen and Phenobarbital Tablets Recalled
Teaser: Mislabeled bottles may result in patients unintentionally taking one product instead of the other, with potentially serious harm.

Headlines: Bevacizumab Linked to Fatal Adverse Effects in Cancer Patients
Teaser: A meta-analysis shows that this cancer drug may be associated with an increased risk for treatment-related death.

Headlines: Contrave Naltrexone/Bupropion Sent Back for CVD Study
Teaser: The drug, a combination of naltrexone and bupropion HCL, had been given a positive decision by the majority of members on an FDA advisory group panel in December.

Headlines: Drug-Induced Deaths More Common Than Alcohol- or Firearm-Related Fatalities
Teaser: A new report from the CDC finds rates of drug-induced deaths are significantly higher for males than females, especially for non-Hispanic white and black males.

Headlines: FAST-MI Registry on Clopidogrel-PPI Interaction
Teaser: The observation was independent of whether patients carried a gene variant also associated with reduced clopidogrel effectiveness. The findings add yet more observational data to a debate that really could use a solid prospective, randomized trial.

Headlines: Vinorelbine 'Preferred' Chemo in HER2-Positive Advanced Breast Cancer
Teaser: Vinorelbine is not more effective than a taxane, according to a new phase 3 study, but it does have a better toxicity profile.

Headlines: ACE Inhibitors Rather Than ARBs Could Save Can$20 Million Per Year
Teaser: Restricting the prescribing of angiotensin-receptor blockers so that they are given only to patients who are intolerant to ACE inhibitors--as is done in one Canadian province--could save millions of dollars in costs without any adverse effects on cardiovascular health, say the authors of a new paper. But this assumes equivalence of the two drug classes, which is not yet proven, says one observer.

Headlines: Risk for Death After Trauma Higher in Patients Using Warfarin
Teaser: Warfarin use is associated with a significant increase in death among injured patients, even after adjustment for confounding comorbidities.

Headlines: Choose Azithromycin as a Macrolide if Patient Is on a CCB
Teaser: Doctors need to be aware of an underappreciated risk of hypotension associated with the use of calcium-channel blockers together with macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin and clarithromycin, Canadian researchers say. If a macrolide-type antibiotic is needed, azithromycin--which does not increase the risk of hypotension--is a better choice, they state.

Headlines: Steroid-Dopamine Combination May Be Fatal in Septic Shock
Teaser: Steroids plus dopamine therapy are linked to increased mortality in patients with shock, especially those with septic shock.

Headlines: Propofol Infusion Syndrome Real but Rare
Teaser: Propofol infusion syndrome is a real but rare entity that can be completely prevented with a simple protocol.

Headlines: EMA Also Wants Liver Warnings Added to Dronedarone Labeling
Teaser: Following in the footsteps of action taken in the US last week, the European Medicines Agency says urgent changes need to be made to the product information for dronedarone, indicating a possible association with liver complications.

Headlines: Sarkozy Vows Health System Fix After Drug Furor
Teaser: French President Nicolas Sarkozy pledged on Thursday to shake up the healthcare system and root out fraud after a report said a drug suspected of killing more than 500 people should have been pulled years before it was.

Headlines: IMRT for Anal Cancer Associated With Fewer Adverse Events
Teaser: Without affecting 2-year outcomes, intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) had fewer adverse events than conventional radiation therapy.

Headlines: Tylenol Products Recalled
Teaser: The products were made at facility where cleaning procedures were insufficient or not adequately documented.

Headlines: Few Women With RA Use Contraindicated Drugs During Pregnancy
Teaser: Only a small minority of women with rheumatoid arthritis are prescribed drugs that are contraindicated during pregnancy, but those who do take them have higher rates of spontaneous abortion.

Headlines: Dronedarone Linked to Liver Damage, Transplants, Says Sanofi
Teaser: Sanofi Aventis has sent out a letter to US healthcare professionals alerting them to an association between severe hepatic injury, including two liver transplants, and use of its anti-arrhythmic drug, dronedarone (Multaq). The company says it will also change the prescribing information for the product, although it stresses no causal association has yet been established. The FDA has also issued a

Headlines: FDA Still Evaluating Insulin Glargine and Possible Cancer Risk
Teaser: The evidence showing an increased cancer risk associated with insulin glargine remains inconclusive, but the FDA is continuing its safety review of the product.

Headlines: Tuberculosis Therapy in Older Patients Linked to Increased Adverse Events
Teaser: The risk for adverse events requiring hospitalization was significantly increased in patients older than 65 years receiving treatment of latent tuberculosis infection.

Headlines: Early Antibiotic Use Linked to Asthma and Allergy at Age 6 Years
Teaser: A cohort study shows that antibiotic use by age 6 months is associated with asthma and allergy at age 6 years and that protopathic bias is unlikely to explain the main findings.

Headlines: Fish Oil Helps Prevent Weight and Muscle Loss in Cancer Patients
Teaser: Fish oil supplementation might prevent the muscle and weight loss that commonly occurs in cancer patients during chemotherapy.

Headlines: Abacavir Does Not Raise MI Risk, FDA Analysis Shows
Teaser: Conflicting information about abacavir's myocardial infarction risk prompted the FDA to study 26 clinical trials involving the drug in HIV-infected patients.

Headlines: Some Immune-Modifying Biologics Are Safer Than Others
Teaser: Patients taking immune-modulating biologics are also likely to experience adverse effects and tuberculosis reactivation vs patients receiving placebo.

Headlines: Coadministration of Flu, Pneumococcal Vaccines Linked to Febrile Seizures
Teaser: CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) discusses febrile seizures associated with vaccine use.

Headlines: Negative Drug Rechallenge After Skin Reaction Predicts Long-Term Tolerance
Teaser: A French study shows that patients with skin reactions to drugs who do not react to a rechallenge will likely exhibit tolerance to the drugs during the long term.

Headlines: Congress Slams FDA Over Heparin Saga, Again
Teaser: Representatives of the House Energy and Commerce committee are asking the agency to supply documents relating to the investigation and tests, to be delivered within two weeks.

Headlines: New Details on Osteonecrosis Risk With Bisphosphonates
Teaser: Two new studies report an association between bisphosphonate use and osteonecrosis of the jaw.

Headlines: High Court Protects Vaccine Makers for 'Unavoidable' Adverse Events
Teaser: Parents still have recourse through the federally mandated "Vaccine Court."

Headlines: Long-Term Use of Bisphosphonates Increases Risk for Atypical Fractures
Teaser: Among older women, treatment with a bisphosphonate for more than 5 years was linked to an increased risk, but a low absolute risk, for subtrochanteric or femoral shaft fractures.

Headlines: Risks With Antipsychotics in Pregnancy Stressed in New Label
Teaser: Taking these medications during the third trimester of pregnancy puts neonates at risk for abnormal muscle movements and withdrawal symptoms.

Headlines: Bleomycin Being Underdosed in Advanced Germ Cell Tumors?
Teaser: A study of bleomycin toxicity showed that asymptomatic drops in lung function scores caused 20% of bleomycin doses to be missed and 20% of patients to receive less than their planned doses.

Headlines: Boxed Warnings Not Ordered Systematically
Teaser: Within a given drug class, 1 agent may have a boxed warning, but others may not. The FDA should require the labels of same-class drugs without warnings to explain this omission.

Headlines: Lots of Jantoven, other agents recalled
Teaser: Upsher-Smith has expanded its recall from one lot to 16 lots of its Jantoven brand of warfarin sodium and has added lots of amlodipine and other drugs.

Headlines: Advantage to Radiation Plus Chemo in Hodgkin's Lymphoma
Teaser: Despite concerns about serious long-term effects, a meta-analysis found a clear advantage to giving both radiation and chemotherapy, compared with chemotherapy alone.

Headlines: Acid-Suppressive Medication Not Preferred Treatment Outside ICU
Teaser: Although acid-suppressive medication protected against nosocomial gastrointestinal tract bleeding, the number needed to treat to prevent 1 case was relatively high.

Headlines: PPI Use May Reduce Antifracture Efficacy of Bisphosphonate Treatment
Teaser: In an observational study, concurrent proton-pump inhibitor use was associated with a dose-dependent loss of protection against hip fracture treatment in elderly patients.

Headlines: NSAIDs May Worsen Pneumonia Outcomes
Teaser: The benefits of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs in the treatment of lower respiratory tract infection may be outweighed by a delayed diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia.

Headlines: Risk for Local Reaction to Fifth Dose of DTap Vaccine Higher With Arm Injection
Teaser: Risk for a local reaction to the fifth dose of the diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertussis vaccine is significantly higher when it is injected in the arm.

Headlines: FDA Adds 13 Drugs to Watch List
Teaser: A drug's appearance on the FDA's watch list does not mean the agency has concluded it necessarily triggers the adverse event in question.

Headlines: New Rosiglitazone Label
Teaser: The new label has been changed to highlight the increased cardiovascular risks with the drug, noting that in a meta-analysis of 52 studies, most of which compared rosiglitazone with placebo, the drug was associated with a significantly increased risk of MI.

Headlines: Targeting 2 Pathways May Enhance Antitumor Activity
Teaser: Combining therapies that target MEK and PI3K pathways has the potential to be more effective than either agent used alone.

Headlines: Johnson & Johnson Recalls Even More Tylenol
Teaser: One lot of Tylenol 8-Hour Extended Release caplets is the latest recall.

Headlines: An Antidepressant Reduces the Neurotoxicity of Oxaliplatin
Teaser: New findings might have immediate clinical applications.

Headlines: BMD Decreases After Bariatric Surgery in Adolescents
Teaser: Within 2 years of surgery, bone mineral density levels do not decrease below average for age and sex, but if bone loss continues, it could have long-term consequences.

Headlines: Some Bottles of Citalopram Recalled Due to Mislabeling
Teaser: Certain bottles of the antidepressant citalopram are being recalled because they may actually contain finasteride, which is associated with possible severe side effects in pregnant women.

Headlines: ARB/ACE-Inhibitor Combo a Risk in Clinical Practice
Teaser: Combining the two types of agent has increased the risk of renal dysfunction in clinical trials; the way the drugs are combined in clinical practice doesn't seem to avoid the problem.

Headlines: Risk Allele Flags Carbamazepine Hypersensitivity in Europeans
Teaser: The researchers say adding association of HLA-A*3101 to carbamazepine reactions to the drug label should be considered.

Headlines: Fracture Warning Nixed for OTC Proton Pump Inhibitors
Teaser: Clinicians, however, should remember the possible risk of bone fracture if they advise patients to take an OTC proton pump inhibitor at higher doses or for longer periods than the label calls for.

Headlines: Adding Therapies to Aspirin Increases Risk of GI Bleeds
Teaser: New figures from a UK primary care database confirm that use of clopidogrel, warfarin, NSAIDs or high-dose corticosteroids on top of low-dose aspirin further increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. And the study is one of few to quantify this risk, say the researchers.

Headlines: More Damning Data on Rosiglitazone
Teaser: A new meta-analysis of observational studies shows rosiglitazone to be associated with a higher risk of heart failure, MI, and death than pioglitazone. But despite having been taken off the market in Europe, the REMS restriction for rosiglitazone recommended by the US FDA last September has still not been finalized.

Headlines: American Regent Recalls 2 Lots of Sodium Chloride Injection
Teaser: Two lots of concentrated sodium chloride Injection are being voluntarily recalled because of particulate matter.

Headlines: Morphine/Naltrexone Combo Temporarily Withdrawn
Teaser: King Pharmaceuticals notes that Embeda, a combination of morphine and naltrexone, has been voluntarily withdrawn because "a prespecified stability requirement was not met during routine testing."

Headlines: Analysis Clarifies Drug Choices for People With Type 2 Diabetes
Teaser: In a new analysis, the evidence supports the choice of metformin as first-line therapy but also finds that the long-term benefits and harms of diabetes medications remain unclear.

Headlines: PPIs and Clopidogrel: New Theory May Explain CV Risk Signal
Teaser: Authors of yet another analysis trying to get to the bottom of the real or perceived risk of combining clopidogrel with a proton-pump inhibitor have a new and provocative theory  as to just where the signal of increased events may be coming from.

Headlines: FDA: Avoid Use of Kaletra Oral Solution in Newborns
Teaser: Kaletra oral solution should be avoided in premature or full-term infants for the first 14 days after their due dates because of possible cardiac, renal, or respiratory problems.

Headlines: Japan Halts Prevenar, ActHIB Vaccines After Four Children Die
Teaser: Japan's health ministry has halted the use of vaccines made by Pfizer Inc and Sanofi-Aventis SA to prevent meningitis and pneumonia following the deaths of four children.

Headlines: Regular NSAID Use Linked to Erectile Dysfunction
Teaser: Regular use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs is associated with erectile dysfunction beyond what would be expected because of age and comorbidity.

Headlines: When Birth Control Pills Are OTC, Patient Education Is Crucial
Teaser: American women are crossing the border to buy over-the-counter birth control pills in Mexico, often without realizing when they have contraindications to the pills, researchers say.

Headlines: Drug-Related Poisonings Land Many in ER
Teaser: Emergency departments treat an estimated 700,000  people yearly for drug poisonings, including many children.

Headlines: FDA Pulls Unapproved Cold, Cough, Allergy Drugs From Market
Teaser: The US Food and Drug Administration is requiring a halt to the manufacture and distribution of certain unapproved prescription oral agents.

Headlines: Genetic Biomarkers May Predict Taxane-Induced Neuropathy
Teaser: Several single-nucleotide polymorphisms associated with time to neuropathy in patients receiving paclitaxel therapy have been identified.

Headlines: Correct Acetaminophen Dose Depends on Children's Weight
Teaser: Infant drug labels should spell out dose.

Headlines: Zoledronic Acid Linked With Seizures in Case Reports
Teaser: Use of zoledronic acid for osteoporosis may occasionally be associated with seizures, according to three case reports published online April 20th in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism.

Headlines: Vaccine Critics Claim Court Paid for Autism Cases
Teaser: The study reports that 83 cases of vaccine-caused brain damage receiving federal compensation involved autism. Experts reply that shared symptoms do not make brain damage and autism identical.

Headlines: Absolute Risk for Femur Fracture Low With Bisphosphonates
Teaser: Although there is a high rate of bisphosphonate use among patients with atypical femur fractures, the absolute risk for such fractures is small enough to justify prescribing the drugs.

Headlines: Thyroid Drug Linked to Fracture Risk in Older Adults
Teaser: Among adults 70 years and older, current thyroid treatment was associated with significantly increased fracture risk, with a strong dose-response relationship.

Headlines: FDA: Safety Issue With Investigational Merck Hepatitis Drug
Teaser: U.S. drug reviewers highlighted safety issues with an experimental Merck & Co hepatitis drug, including anemia and reports of psychiatric problems, in documents released on Monday.

Headlines: FDA Adds Further Risk Information to Natalizumab Label
Teaser: The FDA identified a need to better define risk for progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy and increased risk from concomitant immunosuppressants.

Headlines: Nine Drugs Added to FDA Watch List
Teaser: A drug's appearance on the watch list does not mean the agency has determined that the drug necessarily causes the adverse event in question.

Headlines: More Evidence That Gastric Acid-Suppressive Drugs Raise Pneumonia Risk
Teaser: A new study shows that proton pump inhibitors are linked to a higher risk for community-acquired pneumonia, although the underlying mechanism remains unclear.

Headlines: Paracetamol Use in Pregnancy Linked to Childhood Asthma
Teaser: A meta-analysis of studies shows a 21% increase in the risk for childhood asthma associated with use of paracetamol at any time during pregnancy.

Headlines: New vs Old Contraceptives Have Similar Gallbladder Disease Risk
Teaser: The risk for gallbladder disease is virtually the same with newer and older types of birth control pills, according to a comparative safety study.

Headlines: Diet Drug Orlistat Linked to Kidney, Pancreas Injuries
Teaser: A review of patients taking the diet drug orlistat over a seven-year period points to a 2% increase in acute kidney injuries within one year of patients starting the drug. Separately, safety-watchdog Public Citizen is once again petitioning the FDA to remove the drug from the market, citing adverse-event reports.

Headlines: EMA Warns of Hypersensitivity Reactions With Prasugrel
Teaser: The risks of hypersensitivity reactions are considered "uncommon," affecting anywhere from 0.1% to 1.0% of patients treated with prasugrel.

Headlines: FDA Investigating Cancer Risk With Lenalidomide
Teaser: Lenalidomide (Revlimid) may be associated with an increased risk for certain forms of hematologic malignancies, according to the FDA.

Headlines: Ipilimumab Is for Community-Based Oncologists Too, Says Expert
Teaser: It's the first-ever drug to be proven to extend survival in advanced melanoma, and it has life-threatening adverse events.

Headlines: Topical Benzocaine Associated With Methemoglobinemia
Teaser: Benzocaine sprays, gels, and liquids may cause methemoglobinemia, a rare but serious and potentially fatal condition.

Headlines: Ipilimumab Risk Strategy Released by FDA
Teaser: A risk evaluation and mitigation strategy informs healthcare professionals of the serious risks associated with newly approved ipilimumab and recommended management strategies.

Headlines: Risks of Estrogen Therapy May Change With Longer Follow-Up
Teaser: At 10.7-year follow-up of postmenopausal women with prior hysterectomy and estrogen therapy (median, 5.9 years), breast cancer risk was still decreased and other shorter-term risks had lessened.

Headlines: Neck Circumference Linked to Perioperative Respiratory Events
Teaser: High neck circumference could potentially be used to screen children for the risk for perioperative adverse respiratory events.

Headlines: New Tylenol Recall Due to Musty Odor
Teaser: Johnson and Johnson recalls about 60,000 bottles of Tylenol Extra Strength Caplets.

Headlines: Recall of Pain, Headache Meds Because of Label Mix-Up
Teaser: Patients who accidentally take a tablet containing butalbital could experience sedation, lightheadedness, dizziness, and nausea, according to the US Food and Drug Administration.

Headlines: Study Raises Cancer-ARB Question Again
Teaser: In this latest study of diabetic patients treated with ARBs, candesartan was associated with a significant risk of cancer, while there was a trend toward an increased risk with telmisartan. The clinician who first sparked the ARB-cancer controversy says these new data should force the FDA to look again at patient-level data to assess the cancer risk with the drug class.

Headlines: Risperidone Recalled Due to Possible Contamination
Teaser: Manufacturers of the antipsychotic risperidone have initiated a voluntary recall involving 40,000 bottles of the drug due to possible contamination with a wood preservative.

Headlines: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Patients Overdosed With Cytarabine
Teaser: Patients being treated for acute myeloid leukemia receive up to 10 times more cytarabine than necessary, exposing them to excess toxicity but no added efficacy.

Headlines: Pioglitazone for 1 Year May Increase Risk of Bladder Cancer
Teaser: In the FDA's announcement today, the agency stated that information on the drug's label, as well as the patient medication guide, will be revised to include this new information.

Headlines: New Criteria Define Inappropriate Meds in Older Inpatients
Teaser: STOPP criteria define potentially inappropriate medications and are significantly associated with avoidable adverse drug events leading to urgent hospitalization in older persons.

Headlines: Electronic Postdischarge Chart Prevents Adverse Drug Events
Teaser: Hospitalized patients who are receiving high-risk medications such as warfarin, analgesics, or benzodiazepines benefit from having pharmacists involved in discharge planning.

Headlines: Long-Term Doxorubicin Linked to Secondary Oral Cancers
Teaser: Secondary cancers of the oral cavity appear to be associated with long-term treatment with pegylated liposomal doxorubicin in patients with recurrent ovarian cancer.

Headlines: French Regulators Suspend Pioglitazone Citing Cancer Risk
Teaser: The decision to yank the drug was made after a study requested by the drug regulatory authority, AFSSAPS, confirmed a small increase in bladder cancer among patients treated with the diabetes drug.

Headlines: Toxidromes: What Every Critical Care Nurse Should Know
Teaser: Critical care nurses need to be aware of toxidromes, a group of signs and symptoms and/or characteristic effects associated with exposure to a particular substance or class of substances.

Headlines: Drug Product Recall Due to Possible Penicillin Contamination
Teaser: Concerns over potential cross-contamination of nonpenicillin drug products with penicillin have resulted in a nationwide recall of multiple repackaged products.

Headlines: FDA Review Concludes: No Cancer Risk With ARBs
Teaser: An FDA review launched in the wake of a controversial 2010 meta-analysis has concluded that the drugs do not pose a cancer risk to patients. The FDA says it conducted a much larger, more comprehensive review of the data to reach its reassuring conclusions. Not everyone, however, is satisfied.

Headlines: Sulfonamides and Nitrofurantoins OK to Use During Pregnancy
Teaser: An opinion statement says that most antibiotics are safe to use during pregnancy and that pregnant women should not be denied appropriate treatment of infections.

Headlines: Adverse Device-Related Events Are Frequent in Children
Teaser: Adverse outcomes from the use of medical devices in children are frequent but underrecognized.

Headlines: Daily Azithromycin Reduces Acute Exacerbations of COPD
Teaser: A systematic review suggests that antibiotic exposure prenatally or in early childhood may slightly increase the risk for childhood asthma.

Headlines: Antibiotics May Slightly Increase Risk for Childhood Asthma
Teaser: In men with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, use of short- and long-acting inhaled anticholinergic medications is associated with an increased risk for acute urinary retention.

Headlines: Inhaled Anticholinergics Linked to Acute Urinary Retention
Teaser: The product may be associated with an increased risk for necrotizing enterocolitis; healthcare professionals should stop administering the product to premature infants.

Headlines: FDA Warns Against Use of SimplyThick in Premature Infants
Teaser: Results of this study have possible suggestions for long-term aspirin use in the prevention of chronic disease, as aspirin dose appears to be more important than aspirin duration.

Headlines: UK's NICE Wants More Cost-Effectiveness Data on Dabigatran
Teaser: NICE is requesting further cost-effectiveness analyses comparing dabigatran with warfarin using different effectiveness data and different scenarios for reflecting the cost of warfarin monitoring.

Headlines: Deaths Prompt Dabigatran Safety Advisory in Japan
Teaser: According to Boehringer Ingelheim, treatment with Prazaxa, as it is known in Japan, could not be completely ruled out as a cause of death in five patients, one of whom had kidney failure (a contraindication) and four of whom were aged over 80.

Headlines: Jury Still Out on Somatropin and Increased Risk for Death
Teaser: The FDA advises clinicians to still prescribe recombinant human growth hormone even as the agency continues to weigh a French study that linked the therapy to a higher risk for death.

Headlines: New Pioglitazone Label Highlights Bladder-Cancer Risk
Teaser: The updated label states that pioglitazone should not be started in patients with active bladder cancer and should be used with caution in patients with a prior history of bladder cancer.

Headlines: Caution Needed With Dabigatran (Pradaxa)
Teaser: Caution must be exercised when prescribing the new anticoagulant dabigatran to prevent stroke in atrial-fibrillation patients who are elderly and frail, say doctors.

Headlines: FDA Warns Against Fluconazole (Diflucan) in Early Pregnancy
Teaser: The agency says long-term use of fluconazole (Diflucan) in high doses in the first trimester may be associated with birth defects.

Headlines: FDA Warns Against Counterfeit Morning-After Pill
Teaser: An unapproved morning-after pill called Evital has not been shown to be safe or effective in preventing pregnancy, the FDA warns.

Headlines: FDA: Avoid Methylene Blue or Linezolid With Serotonergics
Teaser: The FDA warns that coadministration of either methylene blue or linezolid  and certain serotonergic agents can lead to an interaction triggering serotonin syndrome.

Headlines: EMA Updates on Pioglitazone and Varenicline
Teaser: The European drug regulator is recommending a label change for one drug, and a stay-the-course message for the second.

Headlines: FDA Studying Link Between Bisphosphonates, Esophageal Cancer
Teaser: The agency continues to review studies that reach different conclusions on the possible association between esophageal cancer and the widely prescribed drugs for osteoporosis.

Headlines: Chemo Toxicity May Tip Scales in Advanced Hodgkin's Lymphoma
Teaser: Overall survival nearly evened out in a clinical trial comparing 2 chemotherapy regimens; adverse events might be a deciding factor in choosing one or the other.

Headlines: Etravirine Shows Fewer Neuropsychiatric AEs Than Efavirenz
Teaser: Compared with efavirenz, etravirine appears to be associated with fewer neuropsychiatric adverse events.

Headlines: Single Lot of Calcium Gluconate Injection Recalled
Teaser: American Regent is voluntarily recalling its calcium gluconate injection, USP, 10% 100 mL pharmacy bulk package, lot number 1006, because some vials may contain silicone particles.

Headlines: Benefits of Ovarian Suppression During Breast Cancer Chemo
Teaser: The rate of early menopause is significantly reduced, but any fertility benefit is unknown.

Headlines: New  FDA Watch List Has Drug Making Fifth Straight Appearance
Teaser: Several of the potential signals in 2010 of serious risks for dronedarone, an  antiarrhythmic, have been followed by label changes.

Headlines: H1N1 Flu Vaccine Not Linked to Guillain-Barré Syndrome
Teaser: In a case-control study, the risk for Guillain-Barré syndrome was not increased after pandemic influenza vaccine, but the upper limit did not exclude a potential increase in risk up to 2.7-fold.

Headlines: Thyroid Effects of Generic, Brand-Name Amiodarone Similar
Teaser: The anti-arrhythmic drug amiodarone is linked with similar rates of thyroid effects whether patients take the brand-name drug or a generic, Canadian research shows.

Headlines: Lower Concentration for Oseltamivir Oral Suspension
Teaser: The influenza drug will become available in the new 6 mg/mL formulation this month. The old 12 mg/mL version will remain on the market until supplies run out.

Headlines: FDA Reminds Clinicians About Risks With Belatacept
Teaser: The manufacturer was required to inform clinicians and patients about the risk for posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy when the FDA okayed the kidney transplant drug.

Headlines: Pediatric Collaborative May Reduce Adverse Drug Events
Teaser: A pediatric collaborative addressing systems of medication delivery was associated with lower rates of adverse drug events at participating institutions.

Headlines: Beware Bleeding With SSRIs and Antiplatelets
Teaser: Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitor antidepressants appear to increase the risk of bleeding in patients taking antiplatelet agents, a new study suggests.

Headlines: IMRT Reduces GI and GU Toxicity in Prostate Cancer
Teaser: Men treated with the newer technology had fewer late bowel and rectal complications than those treated with 3D-conformal radiation therapy.

Headlines: 5-Year Data: Hypofractionated Radiation for Prostate Cancer
Teaser: The newer technology reduces treatment time by 2.5 weeks, but late bladder toxicity is a concern.

Headlines: FDA Still 'Concerned' About Drospirenone VTE Risk
Teaser: The US Food and Drug Administration remains concerned about drospirenone-containing oral contraceptives and increased risk for venous thromboembolism.

Headlines: Europeans Looking Again at Orlistat and Liver Injury
Teaser: The European Medicines Agency says that it has started a review of orlistat-containing medicines to determine whether the "very rare cases of hepatic injury have an impact on their benefit/risk profile and conditions of use."

Headlines: French Judges Charge Servier Head in Mediator Scandal
Teaser: French magistrates allege that Jacques Servier engaged in dishonest practices and deception over the drug's quality and falsely obtained authorization to sell the controversial diabetes drug.

Headlines: EMA Recommends Restricting Use of Dronedarone
Teaser: The EMA committee states that because of the increased risk of liver, lung, and cardiovascular adverse events, dronedarone "should only be prescribed after alternative treatment options have been considered."

Headlines: Qualitest Oral Contraceptives Recalled
Teaser: A packaging error has prompted generic drugmaker Qualitest Pharmaceuticals to recall multiple lots of oral contraceptives.

Headlines: Ondansetron Linked to Arrhythmias, FDA Warns
Teaser: The FDA is revising the drug’s label to warn that patients with congenital long QT syndrome may run the risk for torsades de pointes.

Headlines: Nonaspirin NSAID Use Linked to Risk for Renal Cell Cancer
Teaser: Data from 2 prospective studies show an association between long-term use of nonaspirin anti-inflammatory drugs and the risk for renal cell cancer.

Headlines: Clarify Duration of Bisphosphonate Use, FDA Panel Says
Teaser: An FDA panel has advised the FDA to be more specific about the duration of bisphosphonate use for the treatment of osteoporosis.

Headlines: Adverse Drug Reactions Often Preventable
Teaser: A meta-analysis shows that many adverse drug reactions that occur in the hospital and during emergency care are preventable.

Headlines: Incidence of Thromboembolic Events With Cisplatin Too High
Teaser: The incidence of thromboembolic events in patients receiving cisplatin-based chemotherapy is unacceptably high, a retrospective analysis concludes.

Headlines: HCV Therapy Can Cause Mild Depression to Spike
Teaser: Depressive symptoms may worsen during antiviral therapy among patients with hepatitis C virus, and notable changes in patients with subclinical depressive symptoms at baseline may be of most concern.

Headlines: NSAIDs in Early Pregnancy Linked to Risk for Miscarriage
Teaser: A case-control study shows a 2.4-fold increased risk for miscarriage in women who took any type and dosage of nonaspirin nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs in early pregnancy.

Headlines: Atypical Antipsychotic Linked to Life-Threatening Reactions
Teaser: The FDA has issued a warning about the atypical antipsychotic Saphris, which has been linked to serious allergic reactions.

Headlines: Few Adverse Events Linked to Vaccines, IOM Panel Says
Teaser: The expert committee also reported that scientific evidence favors rejecting a causal relationship between autism and the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine.

Headlines: Macrolide Useful in COPD But May Cause Hearing Loss
Teaser: A macrolide antibiotic given daily for 1 year in addition to usual treatment reduced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations and improved quality of life but caused hearing decrements.

Headlines: Biologics for Psoriasis May Not Raise Cardiovascular Risk
Teaser: Use of certain biologic therapies for psoriasis was not associated with a significant difference in rate of major adverse cardiovascular events vs placebo, but the study may have been underpowered.

Headlines: High Doses of SSRI Linked to Abnormal Heart Rhythm
Teaser: The SSRI citalopram should not be used in doses higher than 40 mg/day because of concerns that it may cause abnormal and potentially fatal changes in heart rhythm.

Headlines: Dabigatran: 260 Fatal Bleeds Since Approval Worldwide
Teaser: Events occurred from March 2008 to October 31, 2011. European regulators are monitoring the issue and say that changes to the drug's current usage instructions 'adequately manage the risk of bleeding.'

Headlines: Buflomedil-Containing Drugs May Be Suspended in EU
Teaser: The European Medicines Agency is recommending suspension of all buflomedil-containing medicines.

Headlines: Dronedarone a Hazard in High Risk Patients With Permanent AF
Teaser: The antiarrhythmic, approved for paroxysmal or intermittent AF, upped the risk of stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmic death in patients with permanent AF and other CV risk factors.

Headlines: ASCO Updates Guidelines on Antiemetics
Teaser: New recommendations for preventing vomiting and nausea caused by cancer treatments are published.

Headlines: HIV Patients on HAART Have a Plethora of Ocular Diseases
Teaser: The prevalence of cataracts among HIV-positive patients receiving HAART is 10 times higher than in the rest of the American population, and the cataracts develop at a much younger age.

Headlines: Renal-Assessment Update Issued for Dabigatran
Teaser: Boehringer Ingelheim has agreed with the European Medicines Agencies to issue an update to the labeling for dabigatran.

Headlines: FDA Provides Update on Drospirenone VTE Risk
Teaser: Further analysis of an FDA-funded study provides more evidence that drospirenone-containing oral contraceptives increase risk for venous thromboembolism, the agency says.

Headlines: Thyroid Testing Urged for Cancer Patients On Newer Therapies
Teaser: Newer targeted therapies and immunotherapies are associated with thyroid dysfunction, which can be mistaken for drug toxicity and lead to unnecessary dosage reductions.

Headlines: Sepsis Drug Xigris Pulled From Worldwide Market
Teaser: Physicians should stop ongoing treatment with the drug now that it has failed a new efficacy test, according to the FDA.

Headlines: MS Relapse Seen After Natalizumab Drug Holiday
Teaser: The risks of natalizumab treatment interruption, even with an alternative immunomodulatory therapy, appear to outweigh the theoretical benefits, researchers say.

Headlines: FDA Updates Warnings on Methylene Blue, Linezolid, and Serotonergics
Teaser: The agency now says that combining methylene blue or linezolid with SSRIs and SNRIs can trigger serotonin syndrome, but this risk may not apply to other serotonergic agents.

Headlines: EMA Reviewing Safety of NSAIDs, Clarifies on Pioglitazone
Teaser: The EMA has launched a new review of the cardiovascular safety of NSAIDs, while also clarifying a previous opinion on the use of the antidiabetic agent pioglitazone and the risk of bladder of cancer.

Headlines: EMA Review Concludes: No Cancer Risk With ARBs
Teaser: The European Medicines Agency "concludes that benefit/risk balance of angiotensin-II-receptor antagonists remains positive," a press release from the agency states today.

Headlines: Erectile Dysfunction Common With Colorectal Cancer Treatment
Teaser: A small survey found that most men developed erectile dysfunction after their colorectal cancer treatment, and that it caused "profound distress."

Headlines: Dabigatran: Australia Issues Bleeding Warning
Teaser: The Australian regulatory authority has issued a "safety advisory" on the new oral anticoagulant dabigatran because of an increase in the number of bleeding-related adverse events reports received since it was approved for use in AF patients.

Headlines: Long-Term Pulmonary Toxicity From Breast Irradiation
Teaser: There is good news from the first study -- a randomized trial -- reporting long-term toxicity outcomes after breast cancer therapy.

Headlines: Fuel to the Fire or Flame Retardant? More on ARB Use/Cancer
Teaser: The use of angiotensin-receptor blockers or ACE inhibitors is not associated with a significantly increased risk of cancer, according to a new meta-analysis. The findings add yet another twist to the debate over whether or not the antihypertensive medications are associated with increased cancer incidence.

Headlines: Reassuring Findings on Anticholinergics in Dementia Patients
Teaser: New research suggests that medications with mild anticholinergic effects don't cause further cognitive decline in patients with Alzheimer's disease.

Headlines: Clopidogrel Hypersensitivity Treated With Steroids a Success
Teaser: A new study has confirmed that virtually all patients with allergic reactions to clopidogrel respond favorably to a three-week course of prednisone, without having to interrupt antiplatelet therapy.

Headlines: More Data Reignite Debate on ARB-Lung Cancer Risk
Teaser: A new study, this time in kidney-transplant recipients, has found that those who took ACE inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers had an increased risk of respiratory tumors if they also had a history of smoking. Some dismiss the findings, but others say they warrant further investigation.

Headlines: Contaminated Cardiac Drugs Kill More Than 100 in Pakistan
Teaser: More than 100 people have died in Pakistan and hundreds more have been hospitalized after having received contaminated cardiac drugs.

Headlines: Most Adverse Events in Hospitals Go Unreported
Teaser: The main reason for incidents falling through the cracks is that staff does not perceive the event as reportable, says a new study from HHS. Nurses did most of the reporting that occurred.

Headlines: Pharmacists' Role Critical to Patient Safety
Teaser: Pharmacists play a key role in reducing adverse drug events and improving patient safety during care transitions.

Headlines: FDA Warns About Potential Mix-Ups With Durezol and Durasal
Teaser: Because the product names are similar, a pharmacist accidentally dispensed the wart remover instead of the prescription eye drops to a patient, leading to a serious injury.

Headlines: Adverse Events When Aliskiren Added to ACE, ARB Therapy
Teaser: Data and safety monitors for ALTITUDE noted that patients in the trial taking aliskiren instead of placebo on top of ACE or ARB therapy experienced an increased incidence of nonfatal stroke, renal complications, hyperkalemia, and hypotension.

Headlines: FDA to Study Death of Patient After First Fingolimod Dose
Teaser: The agency said it still believes the benefits of the drug to treat relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis outweigh potential risks. The cause of the patient's death remains to be determined.

Headlines: FDA Revises Dose for Simvastatin With Amiodarone
Teaser: The agency is raising the allowed dose for simvastatin in combination with the cardiac drug back to 20 mg after mistakenly lowering it to 10 mg in June.

Headlines: Riata ICD Lead 'Alert' Is Now a Class I Recall
Teaser: The US FDA has designated a recent physician advisory letter relating to St Jude Medical's Riata family of ICD leads as a class I recall, the most serious. The letter, issued last month, warned doctors that more leads than it first thought were affected by a problem related to insulation failure.

Headlines: American Dental Association Updates Osteonecrosis Guidelines
Teaser: Shifting away from an emphasis on intravenous bisphosphonates, the American Dental Association Council on Scientific Affairs points to a dose-response effect with antiresorptive therapy.

Headlines: Baseline 'Bother' Predicts Quitting Aromatase Inhibitors
Teaser: What is associated with postmenopausal women discontinuing aromatase inhibitors?

Headlines: New Evidence Addresses ADHD Meds and Adult CVD Risk
Teaser: A large observational study provides reassuring news on the safety of medications for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in middle-aged adults, researchers say.

Headlines: FDA Investigating Serious Bleeding Events With Dabigatran
Teaser: The agency wants to know whether bleeding events are occurring more commonly than would be expected based on data from the RE-LY trial.

Headlines: FDA Relaxes REMS Requirements on 2 Low Platelet Drugs
Teaser: The US FDA has dropped a requirement that prescribers and patients enroll in a monitoring network to use Nplate and Promacta, among other changes.

Headlines: Don't Use Vemurafenib in Earlier-Stage Melanomas
Teaser: Could RAF inhibitors cause other cancers over time?

Headlines: Tenofovir Associated With Nonreversible Kidney Disease
Teaser: Tenofovir for treating HIV is associated with increased risk for kidney disease; this risk does not appear to be reversible after discontinuation.

Headlines: 4 Drugs Cause Most Adverse-Event Hospital Stays for Seniors
Teaser: Most emergency hospitalizations for seniors caused by adverse drug events involve a handful of anticoagulants and diabetes medications, according to a new study.

Headlines: Merck Vioxx Payout in US Approaches $1 Billion
Teaser: Concluding a long-running investigation into promotion of its COX-2 inhibitor, rofecoxib, Merck has agreed to pay out almost $1 billion to the US federal government and most states. But the company still does not admit any wrongdoing with regard to the cardiovascular safety of the drug.

Headlines: Joint Supplements for Aromatase Inhibitor Adverse Effects
Teaser: In combination, glucosamine and chondroitin appear to ease joint pain and improve function in breast cancer patients taking aromatase inhibitors.

Headlines: Adverse CNS Effects of HCV Treatment Discourage Adherence
Teaser: Medications for hepatitis C virus (HCV) can exacerbate cognitive deficits that are already seen in patients with chronic liver disease, and pose a risk to treatment adherence.

Headlines: Transapical TAVI Stopped Due to Adverse Events: STACCATO
Teaser: A study comparing the transapical approach for transcatheter aortic-valve implantation against conventional aortic-valve replacement surgery was stopped early due to an increase in adverse events, including an increased risk of major stroke and severe paravalvular leakage, in elderly patients eligible for surgery.

Headlines: EMA Recommends New Warnings on Osteoporosis Drug
Teaser: The CHMP has confirmed a positive benefit-risk balance for strontium ranelate, but recommends new contraindications and revised warnings.

Headlines: New Report: Cancer and CVD After Radiation Therapy
Teaser: Radiation therapy saves lives but might induce diseases that threaten once again to take them away.

Headlines: Steroids Linked to Suicide, Neuropsychiatric Disorders
Teaser: Glucocorticoids, which are widely used to treat asthma, rheumatoid arthritis, and other autoimmune diseases, have been linked to a significant risk for suicide, mania, delirium, and depression.

Headlines: FDA: New Risks for Statins With HIV/HCV Protease Inhibitors
Teaser: Interactions between 4 statins and protease inhibitors can increase statin exposure and cause muscle injury, including a form that can lead to kidney failure.

Headlines: New Option for Common Capecitabine Adverse Effect?
Teaser: Hand-foot syndrome occurs in many colorectal cancer patients treated with this chemotherapy. Can an anti-inflammatory help?

Headlines: Phosphate Enemas May Be Deadly in Elderly: Report
Teaser: Sodium phosphate enemas may cause older people to suffer kidney failure or even die, a new report suggests.

Headlines: Some FDA Warnings Have Minimal Effect
Teaser: A new study finds that many US Food and Drug Administration drug risk communications have a delayed effect, unintended consequences, or no effect.

Headlines: Over 1300 Deaths in Mediator Scandal in France
Teaser: The number of deaths attributable to heart-valve insufficiency as a result of the use of benfluorex in France is likely more than double that previously thought, a new investigation finds.

Headlines: Chemotherapy During Pregnancy Appears Safe for Offspring
Teaser: Children exposed to chemotherapy during the prenatal period appear to develop as well as those in the general population, without increased cardiac or neurologic morbidity.

Headlines: Boceprevir May Make Some HIV Drugs Less Effective, FDA Warns
Teaser: The FDA warns clinicians and patients about "important" drug interactions between boceprevir and ritonavir-boosted anti-HIV protease inhibitors.

Headlines: Fatal Adverse Events with Pazopanib, Sorafenib, Sunitinib
Teaser: These targeted therapies represent a major step forward in the treatment of cancer, but are associated with fatal adverse events.

Headlines: Bisphosphonates Raise Contralateral Atypical Fracture Risk
Teaser: A study of atypical femur fractures shows an increase in contralateral fractures in patients continuing bisphosphonates.

Headlines: Proton Pump Inhibitors Linked to C difficile Diarrhea
Teaser: The FDA is warning that PPIs may be associated with a higher risk for Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, a persistent illness that comes with abdominal pain and fever.

Headlines: FDA Panel Raises Concerns Over ADHD Drug Labeling
Teaser: The FDA's Pediatric Advisory Committee has recommended labeling changes for an attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder drug and discussed adverse effects.

Headlines: FDA Says Tamsulosin Safe in Pediatric Patients
Teaser: The panel concurred with the FDA that tamsulosin can return to routine safety monitoring.

Headlines: EBRT More Costly, Toxic Than Other Prostate Cancer Therapies
Teaser: External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) for prostate cancer is more costly and more toxic than either prostatectomy or brachytherapy.

Headlines: FDA Panel Says Omalizumab Safe in Pediatric Patients
Teaser: The Pediatric Advisory Committee Panel has recommended a return to routine monitoring in patients aged 6 to 11 years who are receiving omalizumab.

Headlines: HPV Vaccine Policy: At Odds With Evidence-Based Medicine?
Teaser: According to a new study, there is a major discrepancy in claims regarding the safety and efficacy of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines.

Headlines: Oxaliplatin Has Few Benefits, High Toxicity in Rectal Cancer
Teaser: Long-term results from the French ACCORD 12 trial show that adding oxaliplatin to capecitabine plus radiotherapy does not improve survival in rectal cancer.

Headlines: IMRT Slows Radiation-Related Osteoradionecrosis
Teaser: Osteoradionecrosis appears delayed with intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT); however, some complications still occur.

Headlines: Are Calcium Channel Blockers Radioprotective?
Teaser: Antihypertensive medications might block late radiotherapy toxicity, but there are still many questions.

Headlines: FDA Updates Safety Information for Lenalidomide
Teaser: In an update to their ongoing review, the FDA has added safety information to lenalidomide's labeling to inform patients and physicians of an increased risk for secondary cancers.

Headlines: New Antivirals Show Poor Safety in HCV With Cirrhosis
Teaser: Two direct-acting antiviral drugs have poor safety profiles in compensated cirrhotic patients with hepatitis C virus (HCV), including many serious adverse events, but good efficacy.

Headlines: Boceprevir Not Recommended With Certain HIV Drugs, FDA Says
Teaser: Combining the hepatitis C drug with HIV drugs boosted by ritonavir for coinfected patients can lessen the effectiveness of the drugs, according to the agency.

Headlines: Race and Perioperative Pain, Opioid Adverse Events in Children
Teaser: Children of different races have unequal burdens of perioperative pain and risks of opioid-related adverse effects, according to a report today in Pediatrics.

Headlines: Telaprevir May Cause Severe Cutaneous Eruptions
Teaser: The antiviral agent telaprevir (Incivek) has been associated with severe cutaneous eruptions, including the DRESS syndrome (drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms).

Headlines: FDA Issues Warning on Fentanyl Patches
Teaser: The new warning reiterates appropriate use of the patches to prevent life-threatening accidental exposure to the drug, particularly in children.

Headlines: Benefits and Risks of Trastuzumab in Breast Cancer
Teaser: A systematic review shows that trastuzumab significantly increases survival in women with HER2-positive breast cancer, but also puts them at risk for heart problems.

Headlines: FDA Puts 16 Drugs on Watch List
Teaser: Homicidal thoughts are a potential issue for 1 of the 16 drugs added to the agency watch list, but a drug's appearance does not mean the FDA has concluded that it causes the adverse event in question.

Headlines: PML Reported in MS Patient on Fingolimod
Teaser: Novartis today reported a case of PML in a multiple sclerosis patient taking fingolimod.

Headlines: FDA Announces Safety Label Changes to Finasteride
Teaser: Updated labels for finasteride (1 mg and 5 mg) will warn that some sexual adverse effects may linger after the drugs are discontinued.

Headlines: FDA Adds VTE Risk to Drospirenone Label
Teaser: Patients using oral bisphosphonates for the first time may be at increased risk of developing scleritis and uveitis.

Headlines: Bisphosphonates May Increase Risk for Uveitis and Scleritis
Teaser: If the FDA follows the recommendations, drug companies will have to either conduct phase 2 to 3 trials or do meta-analyses that rule out excess cardiovascular risk for new obesity drugs that do not have a signal for cardiovascular risk. Advisors voted 17 to 6 in favor of a cardiovascular-safety benchmark that equals the one for diabetes drugs.

Headlines: 'Safe' Obesity Drugs Need to Prove Absence of CV Risk
Teaser: In day one of a two-day meeting, members of the FDA Endocrinologic and Metabolic Drugs Advisory Committee heard from experts in obesity, diabetes, cardiology, and statistics. Later today, the panel will vote on whether obesity drugs with no cardiovascular risk signal still need to rule out excess cardiovascular risk.

Headlines: FDA Committee Grapples With CV Risks in Obesity Drugs
Teaser: Treatment-induced menopausal symptoms in breast cancer patients can be considerably ameliorated with cognitive behavioral therapy and physical exercise.

Headlines: Treatment-Induced Menopause Helped by Nondrug Therapies
Teaser: Citalopram, a commonly used SSRI, should not be used in doses greater than 20 mg/day in adults over 60 due to an increased risk of QT prolongation.

Headlines: Lower Citalopram Dose Needed in Older Patients, FDA Warns
Teaser: A hallmark of the toxic effects seems to be cutaneous necrosis on the ears and the appearance of autoantibodies.

Headlines: Levamisole-Laced Cocaine May Unmask Autoimmune Process
Teaser: A study shows that using more dental sedatives increases the rate of complications in pediatric dental patients.

Headlines: Added Complications With More Dental Sedatives for Children
Teaser: Black patients are at greatest risk for ventilatory-assisted hospitalization.

Headlines: Prostate Cancer AEs Persist 5 to 10 Years After Treatment
Teaser: Average sexual and urinary dysfunction is still 'very poor' up to 10 years after treatment, a study finds.

Headlines: Lot of Vecuronium Bromide Under Recall
Teaser: The US Food and Drug Administration has announced a voluntary manufacturer recall of one lot of injectable vecuronium bromide.

Headlines: Antipsychotics Linked to Gestational Diabetes
Teaser: Women who use antipsychotics during pregnancy may be at risk of developing gestational diabetes, and their babies may be at risk for increased head circumference.

Headlines: Voluntary Drug Event Reporting Systems Woefully Lacking
Teaser: Health systems need to move beyond methods for adverse drug event detection that rely primarily on voluntary reporting and should use several different methods to detect multiple types of events.

Headlines: FDA Issues Update on QT Prolongation Risk With Ondansetron
Teaser: The 32-mg single intravenous dose of ondansetron should be avoided, as it may cause QT interval prolongation and could lead to a potentially fatal heart arrhythmia.

Headlines: Olmesartan Linked to Rare Serious GI Side Effects
Teaser: A report from the Mayo Clinic suggests some patients on the hypertension drug olmesartan are at risk for severe intestinal inflammation.

Headlines: Vitamin B12 Deficiency With Metformin Linked to Neuropathy
Teaser: In patients with type 2 diabetes taking metformin, vitamin B12 deficiency is linked to increased peripheral neuropathy.

Headlines: Acceptable Thrombosis Risk With Hormonal Contraceptives
Teaser: In the largest-ever study to look at arterial thrombotic complications as a result of the use of hormonal contraception, Danish researchers find the risks are, for the most part, acceptable, given the benefits of these products.

Headlines: Glucarpidase for Methotrexate Toxicity Oncologic Emergency
Teaser: Cancer patients on high-dose methotrexate who develop renal impairment and acute toxicity can be rescued with a single dose of the new agent.

Headlines: Statins Linked to Fatigue in Randomized Study
Teaser: Moderate doses of both simvastatin and pravastatin were associated with tiredness and exertional fatigue in what is thought to be the first randomized study to look at such adverse effects with statins.

Headlines: Duloxetine Useful in Chemo Neuropathy, But Avoid ALC
Teaser: The antidepressant alleviated chemotherapy-induced neuropathy in what is described at a practice-changing trial, but patients with breast cancer should avoid acetyl-L-carnitine (ALC) supplements.

Headlines: Contraceptives Recalled Because of Packaging Flaw
Teaser: The US Food and Drug Administration is notifying healthcare professionals of a voluntary recall of levonorgestrel and ethinyl estradiol tablets (Introvale, Sandoz) because of a packaging flaw.

Headlines: EU Medicines Agency Launches Adverse Drug Event Web Site
Teaser: In a move aimed at improving transparency, suspected side effects with any medicine approved via the centralized EU approvals procedure can now be searched on a new website.

Headlines: Oral Methylnaltrexone for Opioid-Induced Constipation
Teaser: DDW 2012: Half the patients responded to daily dosing.

Headlines: Genetic Markers Linked to Prostate Radiation Toxicity
Teaser: Identifying susceptibility markers could guide therapy in the future.

Headlines: Lack of Awareness of Late Drug Effects in Cancer Survivors
Teaser: Very few primary care physicians are aware of all the main long-term complications from 4 commonly used chemotherapies.

Headlines: 'One-Two Punch' for Advanced Melanoma Is Less Toxic
Teaser: Skin toxicities are a concern with new treatments for metastatic melanoma.

Headlines: Olanzapine Reduces Breakthrough Chemo-Induced Emesis
Teaser: In the first study of its kind, olanzapine was significantly more effective than metoclopramide in stopping breakthrough chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Headlines: FDA to Review CV Risk With Azithromycin
Teaser: In an observational study, during a five-day course of azithromycin therapy, patients had a small, increased chance of dying from sudden cardiac death compared with patients taking amoxicillin. The risk of death was higher among patients with the most baseline cardiovascular risk factors.

Headlines: FDA Warns of Burns From Topical Pain Relievers
Teaser: The US Food and Drug Administration warns of the potential for burns with over-the-counter topical joint and muscle pain relievers.

Headlines: Documented CNS Infections Accompanied Natalizumab Use
Teaser: At least 17 patients taking natalizumab have experienced serious herpes simplex or varicella zoster infections since November 2004.

Headlines: Public Citizen Sues FDA Over Safety of High-Dose Donepezil
Teaser: A consumer watchdog group charges the FDA with not acting on its May 2011 petition to pull the 23-mg dose of donepezil from the market because of safety concerns.

Headlines: Aloe Vera Reduces Severity of Dermatitis After Radiotherapy
Teaser: The prophylactic use of topical aloe vera, an ancient herbal remedy, significantly reduces the severity of radiation-induced dermatitis.

Headlines: Risk for Heart Failure With Trastuzumab Higher Than Believed
Teaser: Clinical trials have shown that anthracyclines and trastuzumab together increased the risk for heart failure; that risk appears to be even higher in a real-world setting.

Headlines: Olanzapine Activates Food Reward Area of the Brain
Teaser: A new imaging study shows that olanzapine can trigger anticipatory responses to food in specific areas of the brain after just 1 week of treatment, contributing to significant weight gain.

Headlines: Antiepilepsy Drug Rufinamide Tied to Weight Loss
Teaser: Nearly half of the patients taking rufinamide for epilepsy in a new case series developed clinically significant weight loss, according to French researchers.

Headlines: New Anticancer Drugs Associated With Increased Toxicity
Teaser: Many of the new anticancer agents improve effectiveness, but they also increase morbidity and mortality because of their toxicity.

Headlines: Diabetes: Another Late Complication of Radiotherapy
Teaser: Among other late effects, cancer survivors who underwent abdominal or total body radiotherapy have an increased risk for diabetes.

Headlines: Statin Potency Linked With Muscle Weakness
Teaser: The highest rates of muscle-related adverse effects are associated with the strongest statin drugs.

Headlines: Fluoroquinolones Tied to Higher Risk of Serious Arrhythmias
Teaser: Fluoroquinolones, especially gatifloxacin, moxifloxacin and ciprofloxacin, are associated with significantly increased risks of serious arrhythmias, according to a new study.

Headlines: FDA Warns of Codeine Overdose Risk After Pediatric Surgery
Teaser: A small percentage of children convert appropriate doses of codeine into potentially lethal levels of morphine in their bloodstream.

Headlines: Statins Linked With Development of Cataracts
Teaser: Statin users are more than 50% likelier to develop age-related cataracts than nonusers, according to the results of a new study. And those with type 2 diabetes taking statins were at even greater risk, say the researchers.

Headlines: Photosensitizing Antihypertensives Raise Lip Cancer Risk
Teaser: Patients initiating hydrochlorothiazide or another photosensitizing agent need a reminder to avoid sun exposure, researchers say.

Headlines: Sirolimus Cuts Skin Cancer Risk in Transplant Patients
Teaser: A switch to sirolimus appears to reduce the risk for new skin cancers in kidney transplant patients.

Headlines: Calcitonin Linked to Cancer Risk, EMA Warns
Teaser: The European version of the FDA is recommending market withdrawal of calcitonin nasal spray, used to treat osteoporosis. Two brand-name versions are marketed in the United States.

Headlines: FDA Puts 4 Drugs, X-Ray Contrast Agent on Watch List
Teaser: An appearance on the list does not mean that the FDA has determined that the drug actually poses the reported health risk.

Headlines: Leucovorin Calcium Lots Subject to Voluntary Recall
Teaser: Three lots of leucovorin calcium lots subject to recall due to evidence of particulate matter.

Headlines: Platinum-Induced Ototoxicity in Children a Continuing Issue
Teaser: New recommendations have been made related to otoprotection in children receiving platinum-based chemotherapy, including a new ototoxicity scale.

Headlines: Avoiding Severe Toxicity From 5-FU and Related Drugs
Teaser: A multiparametric approach to screening identifies more patients who are likely to suffer toxic effects and who might even die from 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and related chemotherapies.

Headlines: 32-Mg IV Zofran Pulled From Market
Teaser: This particular dose of the antinausea drug can lead to a deadly heart rhythm, says the FDA, which expects voluntary recalls of generic versions as well.

Headlines: Greater Monitoring of Clozapine for Serious AEs Needed
Teaser: Current guidelines require monitoring for agranulocytosis when using clozapine to treat schizophrenia, but new data strongly suggest additional monitoring for other adverse events is warranted.

Headlines: Drugs That Interact With Grapefruit on the Rise
Teaser: The number of drugs that can be risky when taken with grapefruit is on the rise, largely due to the influx of new medications and chemical formulations, a new study shows.

Headlines: New WHI Analysis Links HRT to Atrial Fibrillation
Teaser: Recent linkage of the WHI trials to the Medicare database has allowed researchers to accurately analyze the rate of AF among women taking HRT in the trial and compare it with those who were not taking hormones.

Headlines: History of Atopy May Predict Serious Adverse Drug Reactions
Teaser: People with a history of asthma, eczema, allergic rhinitis, or an adverse reaction to drugs are more likely to have a severe adverse drug reaction to a new medication.

Headlines: Excessive Acetaminophen Dosing Too Common in Hospitals
Teaser: Excessive amounts of acetaminophen were given to at least 4% of adult inpatients studied, according to a retrospective review of the electronic medical records of 14,000 patients.
