Teaser: Members of the US House of Represenatives used a Wednesday hearing to promote use of the measles shot. They also delved into the factors that keep parents from having their children vaccinated.

Headlines: Hypofractionated Radiotherapy Appropriate for Low-Risk Prostate Cancer
Teaser: Hypofractionated radiotherapy (HRT) should be a new practice standard for men with low-risk prostate cancer, based on a secondary analysis of a phase III trial.

Headlines: IPT for Cancer Unproven, May Do Harm
Teaser: When a cancer patient asks about unproven therapies such as insulin-potentiation therapy (IPT), don't brush the question aside: this is a chance to  provide information, say clinicians.

Headlines: Pediatric Medical Overuse Persists
Teaser: Evidence of pediatric medical overuse persists, but there are glimmers of progress, according to a new review.

Headlines: New Recombinant Vaccine Most Cost-Effective Alternative for Preventing Herpes Zoster
Teaser: The new recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is more cost-effective than both the zoster vaccine live (ZVL) and no vaccination for preventing herpes zoster and related complications, according to a model study.

Headlines: Expired Drugs May Remain Effective, Safe to Use in a Pinch
Teaser: Even medicines that are years past their expiration date and haven't always been kept in strict climate-controlled conditions may still retain their original potency, a small study suggests.

Headlines: Fluconazole Tied to Miscarriages
Teaser: Pregnant women who take oral fluconazole to treat vaginal yeast infections may be more likely to have miscarriages than women who don't take this pill during pregnancy, a Canadian study suggests.

Headlines: Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy Shows Long-Term Safety in Prostate Cancer
Teaser: Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) appears to provide good long-term results and very few toxic effects in certain prostate cancers, according to data from thousands of patients.

Headlines: Five Dermatologic Emergencies Physicians Should Recognize
Teaser: These 'are the ones that, if you miss the diagnosis, you end up with a lot more morbidity and mortality than necessary,' an expert says.

Headlines: Americans Going to Mexico to Buy Insulin at Fraction of US Cost
Teaser: For one patient, a three-month supply of insulin is $3,700 in the U.S. versus $600 in Mexico. But is it legal?

Headlines: Mitoxantrone for Childhood Cancer More Cardiotoxic Than Thought
Teaser: In pediatric cancer patients, mitoxantrone appears to be at least ten times as cardiotoxic as doxorubicin therapy, while daunorubicin therapy may be less so, according to a large cohort study.

Headlines: Chemobrain: How It Happens, and Perhaps How It Can Be Stopped
Teaser: New insights into how chemotherapy affects the brain may lead to ways to treat and maybe even prevent the cognitive impact of cancer drugs.

Headlines: Contrast-Agent Allergies Often Poorly Documented in EHR
Teaser: Documentation of contrast-agent allergies in electronic health records (EHRs) often lacks important information, such as the particular agent, according to new research.

Headlines: Weight Gain, Blood Pressure Rise Seen With JAK Inhibitor Therapy
Teaser: Pharmacologic inhibition of Janus kinases (JAK) 1 and 2 is associated with significant weight gain and increased systolic blood pressure, according to a review of patients treated with the JAK1/2 inhibitor ruxolitinib.

Headlines: In Pursuit of the Lost Taste of Chocolate
Teaser: One of the side-effects of chemotherapy in cancer patients is dysgeusia, an impaired sense of taste that can leave a patient's favorite foods, such as chocolate, with no flavor at all.

Headlines: Amphotericin B Makes Path for Lung Defense in Cystic Fibrosis
Teaser: Amphotericin B treatment may be able to restore the infection-fighting properties of the lungs in cystic fibrosis by standing in for a missing or deficient protein channel, studies in pigs and in human lung tissue suggest.

Headlines: Preop Immune-modulating Nutrition Improves Outcomes After GI-cancer Surgery
Teaser: Preoperative immune-modulating nutrition (IMN) in patients undergoing surgery for gastrointestinal cancer reduces the risk of infectious complications and shortens hospital stays, according to a new systematic review and meta-analysis.

Headlines: Cannabis-Linked ED Visits: Smoking vs Eating Matters
Teaser: Cannabis-related visits to the emergency department spiked in Colorado after marijuana was legalized there, with visits as a result of inhalable use being more frequent than from edible use.

Headlines: Worry After Prostatectomy a Self-fulfilling Prophecy
Teaser: Three years after a radical prostatectomy, men with the personality trait of neuroticism scored worse on urinary, bowel, sexual, and hormonal domains.

Headlines: Asthma Medication Use Varies Among Latino Youth
Teaser: A new U.S. study of groups of Latino youth with asthma sheds light on potential health disparities. Puerto Rican children were less likely than Mexican kids to use asthma inhalers regularly, researchers found.

Headlines: Severe Adverse Events When Osimertinib Follows Immunotherapy
Teaser: Severe immune-related adverse events have been observed when osimrtinib was given after, but not before, immune checkpoint inhibitors in patients with advanced NSCLC.

Headlines: No Survival Benefit for Volatile Anesthesia in Elective CABG Surgery
Teaser: In a comparison of gas versus needle, a new pragmatic trial has shown that using a volatile anesthesia agent during elective coronary-artery bypass grafting (CABG) did not produce fewer deaths after one year.

Headlines: Shaving 10 Months Off Treatment Not Inferior Against Rifampin-Resistant TB
Teaser: A new study in patients with rifampin-resistant tuberculosis (TB) is providing the first strong evidence that the Bangladesh protocol for treating multidrug-resistant (MDR)-TB, which is used for 9 to 11 months, is not inferior to the standard regimen recommended by the World Health Organization, which requires treatment for 20 months.

Headlines: Persistent Alopecia After Cancer Treatment Tied to Lower Quality of Life
Teaser: Persistent chemotherapy-induced alopecia (pCIA) is often more severe than endocrine-induced alopecia after chemotherapy (EIAC), but both conditions are associated with a "negative emotional effect," researchers say.

Headlines: In HIV Patients, Isoniazid-Rifapentine Combo Dramatically Cuts TB Prophylaxis Therapy
Teaser: The battery-powered device would be useful in resource-poor countries by allowing women to be screened and then treated immediately by nurses, even when there is no electricity.

Headlines: Portable Thermal Ablation Device for Cervical Precancers
Teaser: Most approved medications have inactive ingredients that could cause problems in patients with allergies or sensitivities to those ingredients, researchers found.

Headlines: Inactive Ingredients in Medications Cause Trouble for Some
Teaser: New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy on Tuesday reached an agreement in principle with Democratic lawmakers for the state to potentially become the second in the country to legalize the recreational use of cannabis though legislation.

Headlines: New Jersey Leaders in Deal to Legalize Recreational Marijuana
Teaser: Poor reporting of study details and small numbers of participants make it difficult to assess interventions for urinary incontinence after stroke, authors of a Cochrane review say.

Headlines: No Evidence-Based Guidance for Treating Post-Stroke Urinary Incontinence
Teaser: Merck has prevailed in a first lawsuit that claimed switching the formulation of levothyroxine in France caused patients harm; the company still faces further claims, however.

Headlines: Merck Wins Lawsuit on Levothyroxine Saga in France
Teaser: In a radiation-proof room at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, Emar Thomasa sits behind shielded glass as he carefully measures and mixes lutetium octreotate, an intravenous treatment for certain types of cancer.

Headlines: Dutch Join Backlash at Expensive Drugs by Making Their Own
Teaser: Allergan Plc said on Wednesday its experimental add-on treatment for depression failed three late-stage studies, casting doubts over its drugs pipeline.

Headlines: Teva Scraps Cluster Headache Program
Teaser: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd said on Tuesday it would stop developing its migraine drug, Ajovy, for treating cluster headaches.

Headlines: Research Needed on Long-Term Osteoporosis Drug Therapies
Teaser: A variety of drugs are effective for preventing osteoporotic fractures, but there are gaps in the evidence supporting their safety and effectiveness beyond three years, according to a National Institutes of Health Pathways to Prevention Workshop.

Headlines: Reporting of Adverse Drug Reactions Differs by Gender
Teaser: Reported adverse reactions to specific drugs show distinct gender differences, new findings show.

Headlines: Rapid Initiation of Single-Tablet, Quadruple Anti-HIV Therapy Effective
Teaser: A high proportion of patients with newly diagnosed HIV-1 infection achieved an undetectable viral load through 48 weeks after starting Symtuza (Janssen) within two weeks of diagnosis, according to new data from the DIAMOND study.

Headlines: Risky AEDs Still Prescribed to Women of Childbearing Age
Teaser: Despite warnings that use of certain antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) during pregnancy carry significant risks for poor outcomes in children, the drugs are still being used at concerning levels.

Headlines: Hyponatremia Linked to Metabolic Bone Disease in Epilepsy
Teaser: In patients with epilepsy, hyponatremia - a common side effect of several antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) - is independently associated with decreased bone-mineral density (BMD) and an increased risk of osteoporosis, researchers from Denmark report.

Headlines: Emergency-Medicine Residents Often Miscalculate IV Doses for Kids
Teaser: Emergency-medicine residents often miscalculate doses for a variety of intravenous medications used to treat children, according to new findings.

Headlines: More Evidence Schizophrenia Combo Therapy Blunts Weight Gain
Teaser: The combination of olanzapine and samidorphan, shown to mitigate the weight gain observed with olanzapine alone in ENLIGHTEN-2, continues to prevent weight gain, new results from an extension study show.

Headlines: U.S. Charges Pummel Drugmaker Indivior, Hurt Reckitt
Teaser: Indivior Plc lost three-quarters of its stock market value on Wednesday and former parent Reckitt Benckiser also fell after the U.S. Justice Department accused the British drugmaker of illegally boosting prescriptions for its blockbuster opioid addiction treatment.

Headlines: Targeted Drug Delivery for Cancer Pain Cuts Costs, Hospital Time
Teaser: Targeted drug delivery (TDD) reduces costs and healthcare utilization when added to conventional medical management (CMM) for patients with cancer-related pain, according to new findings.

Headlines: Zogenix's Seizure Drug Filing Fails to Pass U.S. FDA Scrutiny
Teaser: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Monday refused to fully review the marketing application for Zogenix Inc's treatment for seizures associated with Dravet syndrome, a rare form of childhood epilepsy.

Headlines: Ribaxamase Reduces C. Diff Infection After Beta-Lactam Therapy
Teaser: The beta-lactamase ribaxamase reduces the incidence of Clostridium difficile infections in hospitalized patients treated with intravenous ceftriaxone for lower-respiratory-tract infections, researchers report.

Headlines: FDA Clears New Drug-Sparing Option for HIV Infection
Teaser: The dolutegravir and lamivudine combination (Dovato) is the first once-daily, single-tablet, two-drug regimen for adults with treatment-naive HIV infection.

Headlines: For Psoriasis, Ustekinumab and TNF Inhibitors Show Similar Cardiac Safety
Teaser: In patients with psoriatic disease, the incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF) and major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) does not differ between treatment with ustekinumab and TNF inhibitors, according to a large observational study.

Headlines: FDA Warns Lab Against Marketing Tests Linking Genes, Drug Reaction
Teaser: Inova Genomics is cited for illegally marketing MediMap genetic tests that claim to predict a patient's response to antidepressants and other medications.

Headlines: Umbralisib Shows Promise in Relapsed/Refractory Marginal Zone Lymphoma
Teaser: Umbralisib, an investigational oral inhibitor of PI3K-delta, has significant activity against relapsed/refractory marginal-zone lymphoma (MZL) and manageable side effects, according to early results from an ongoing phase 2b trial.

Headlines: Lenalidomide Plus Rituximab Ups Response in Relapsed Indolent Lymphoma
Teaser: In patients with relapsed or refractory indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma, adding lenalidomide to rituximab improves response, according to a placebo-controlled trial.

Headlines: Persons Living With Incurable Cancer a Growing, Neglected Group
Teaser: Through advances in treatment, an ever-increasing number of people are living with metastatic cancer, presenting a host of challenges that require increased attention.

Headlines: Topical PDE4 Inhibitors Suitable for Mild-to-Moderate Atopic Dermatitis
Teaser: Topical phosphodiesterase 4 (PDE4) inhibitors are safe and effective for the treatment of mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis, researchers in China have found.

Headlines: Preventive Drugs Could Be Safely Discontinued in Elderly With Advanced Cancer
Teaser: Many preventive drugs could be safely discontinued, with substantial cost savings, in the last year of life of older adults with cancer, according to a retrospective study of Swedish data.

Headlines: Sexual Function and Intimacy Impaired in Inflammatory Arthritis
Teaser: Patients with inflammatory arthritis (IA) report significant impairments in sexual function and intimate relationships, researchers from Australia report.

Headlines: Add-On Sotagliflozin Has Benefits, Raises Ketoacidosis Risk in Type 1 Diabetes
Teaser: Add-on dual sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT) 1/2 inhibitor sotagliflozin has benefits in patients with type 1 diabetes, according to a new meta-analysis.

Headlines: Skin Testing Helpful in Patients With Radiocontrast-Media Hypersensitivity
Teaser: Skin testing can be used to differentiate allergy from non-allergic reactions in patients with hypersensitivity to radiocontrast media (RCM) and to identify an alternative, safe RCM, researchers from Germany report.

Headlines: Medical Cannabis Safe, Effective in the Elderly
Teaser: Researchers reported that the drug provided relief from chronic pain, sleep disorders, and anxiety related to a variety of diseases.

Headlines: Oral Fluoroquinolones Carry Small Risk of Peripheral Neuropathy
Teaser: Oral fluoroquinolone exposure is associated with a small increase in risk of peripheral neuropathy, according to findings from The Health Improvement Network (THIN) database.

Headlines: No Edge for Levetiracetam Over Phenytoin for Status Epilepticus
Teaser: Both levetiracetam and phenytoin are reasonable second-line treatment options for pediatric status epilepticus, new research shows.

Headlines: Watchful Waiting OK in Diabetic Macular Edema With Good Vision
Teaser: New trial suggests no difference in risk for vision loss over 2 years with aflibercept, laser treatment, or observation; experts stress importance of adherence to follow-up and tight glycemic control.

Headlines: Adverse Events Common With PD-1 and PD-L1 Inhibitors
Teaser: Most cancer patients treated with programmed cell death (PD-1) and programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitors experience at least one treatment-related adverse event, according to a new systematic review and meta-analysis.

Headlines: Longer Course of Solifenacin Does Not Reduce Overactive Bladder Recurrence
Teaser: Prolonged anti-muscarinic treatment with solifenacin does not decrease the risk for retreatment of overactive bladder, researchers say.

Headlines: Bb2121 CAR-T Multiple Myeloma Treatment Effective, but Benefits May Wane
Teaser: Doctors testing a chimeric antigen receptor T-cell (CAR-T) therapy against relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma say results from 33 patients show a complete response rate of 45%, although 40% of those patients with a complete response ultimately relapsed.

Headlines: Long-Term Methimazole Treatment Benefits Children With Graves' Disease
Teaser: Continuation of methimazole treatment beyond 24 months is associated with significantly higher cure rates in patients with Graves' hyperthyroidism, researchers from Iran report.

Headlines: Higher Colony-Count Threshold for Urinary Pathogens Cuts Antimicrobial Treatment
Teaser: Raising the colony-count threshold for treatment of urinary pathogens in hospitalized patients is associated with reduced antimicrobial use, researchers report.

Headlines: FDA Approves First Vaccine for Dengue, With Restrictions
Teaser: Dengvaxia is for the prevention of dengue disease caused by all dengue virus serotypes in people aged 9 to 16 years who have previously had laboratory-confirmed dengue infection and who live in endemic areas.

Headlines: Pentosan Polysulfate Sodium Treatment Strongly Linked With Maculopathy and Vision Loss
Teaser: Patients taking pentosan polysulfate sodium (PPS), which has been on the market for many years, appear to be at greater risk for a newly described maculopathy and vision loss, researchers report.

Headlines: Immune-Checkpoint-Blockade Toxicity Often Missed in Emergency Departments
Teaser: Emergency medicine physicians commonly miss immune-related adverse events (IRAEs) stemming from immune-checkpoint blockade in patients with cancer, according to a new study from France.

Headlines: Peanut Oral Immunotherapy Safe for Preschoolers in Real-World
Teaser: Oral immunotherapy for peanut allergy is safe in preschool-aged children when given as routine treatment in a hospital or clinic, a new study has found.

Headlines: Regulators Uneven on Safety Warnings on New Drugs
Teaser: FDA ranks third among health authorities in four English-speaking countries in the frequency of postmarketing drug safety warnings, new data show.

Headlines: Adverse Skin Effects Tied to Anti-PD1 Response in Melanoma
Teaser: Cutaneous toxic effects (CT) following treatment with anti-programmed-cell-death 1 (anti-PD-1) inhibitors may be encouraging news in patients with advanced melanoma, a retrospective review suggests.

Headlines: Novel CAR T-Cell Approach Reduces Toxicities, Retains Efficacy
Teaser: The modified molecule for the anti-CD19 CAR T-cell therapy shows signs of reducing the risk for severe cytokine release syndrome while maintaining efficacy.

Headlines: Albuterol Before Tonsillectomy Protects Against Respiratory Problems
Teaser: Preoperative inhaled albuterol can help protect against perioperative respiratory adverse events in young children undergoing anesthesia for tonsillectomy, according to data from the Australian REACT trial.

Headlines: Aquablation Shows "Promising" Outcomes in BPH Patients With Large Prostates
Teaser: Aquablation appears to effectively and safely treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in prostates of up to 150 cc, an industry-funded study suggests.

Headlines: Young Adults See Less Harm in Tobacco Products, Prefer Online Health Information
Teaser: Young adults may be more likely than older folks to go online to find health information, and less likely to view tobacco products as "very harmful," according to survey results compiled to inform U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulatory policy.

Headlines: Bictegravir-Based Regimen Noninferior to Dolutegravir-Based Regimens for HIV Treatment
Teaser: A single-tablet regimen of bictegravir, emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide is noninferior to regimens of dolutegravir coformulated with emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide or with abacavir and lamivudine for the initial treatment of HIV-1 infection, according to results from two randomized phase 3 trials.

Headlines: Previous Seasons' Flu Shots Protective, Less So for Elders
Teaser: Influenza vaccines given in previous seasons still provide some protection against infection, according to a new study.

Headlines: 'Scary World' of Generic Drug Manufacturing, Revealed
Teaser: Doctors noticed problems with the generic drugs their patients took and helped investigative reporter Katherine Eban bring to light systemic issues with the drugs' manufacturing and regulation.

Headlines: Less Toxicity With Proton Beam vs Photon Chemoradiotherapy
Teaser: Survival outcomes were similar compared with traditional photon chemoradiotherapy, but patients treated with proton beam therapy had significantly fewer serious adverse events.

Headlines: Serial-Killer Nurse Jailed for Life in Germany
Teaser: A former nurse was jailed for life on Thursday for murdering 85 of his patients - the worst killing spree in Germany's post-war history.

Headlines: Pembrolizumab an Alternative to Chemo in Some Advanced Stomach Cancers
Teaser: For patients with PD-L1-positive, HER2-negative, advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction (G/GEJ) cancer, front-line treatment with pembrolizumab is noninferior to standard chemotherapy and far less toxic, according to results of the KEYNOTE-062 trial.

Headlines: Amgen Drug Shows High Response Rate in Small Lung and Colon Cancer Trial
Teaser: An experimental Amgen Inc drug that targets a specific genetic mutation significantly reduced tumor size in half of evaluated patients with advanced lung cancer in a small, early-stage trial, researchers said on Monday.

Headlines: Ketamine May Help Teens With Resistant Depression
Teaser: Ketamine produced a significant reduction of depressive symptoms in teens with treatment-resistant depression in this first RCT, but its effects on the developing brain need to be rigorously explored.

Headlines: Methylphenidate Dose Titration in ADHD Should Be Based on Outcomes
Teaser: Dose titration of methylphenidate in patients with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) should aim to maximize the ratio of benefit to adverse effects, as there appears to be no scientific rationale for published maximum doses, according to a meta-analysis.

Headlines: Botox May Help Bipolar Depression, Social Anxiety
Teaser: In two small case series, injections of botulinum toxin into the glabellar region -- the area between the eyebrows and above the nose -- reduced symptoms of bipolar depression and social anxiety.

Headlines: Antipsychotic Side Effects Tough to Take, Patients Say
Teaser: Patients with schizophrenia who take second-generation antipsychotics often suffer side effects that significantly disrupt daily functioning and quality of life.

Headlines: New Regional Dermatoses Can Develop During Dupilumab Treatment
Teaser: Dupilumab treatment of atopic dermatitis can be accompanied by the emergence of new regional dermatoses, according to a retrospective study.

Headlines: Some Systemic Psoriasis Drugs May Carry Lower Risk of Serious Infection
Teaser: Psoriasis patients who start treatment with apremilast, etanercept or ustekinumab have a lower risk of developing a serious infection than those prescribed methotrexate, new findings show.

Headlines: Targeting Vasopressin May Improve Social Deficits in Autism
Teaser: There are currently no medications to address social deficits in autism, but two new studies suggest that vasopressin, a hormone associated with social bonding, may be a viable target for drug development.

Headlines: EU Panel Backs Market Withdrawal of Fenspiride Due to Heart Risk
Teaser: The European Medicines Agency's Pharmacovigilance Risk Assessment Committee recommended revoking marketing authorizations for fenspiride medicines, preventing them from being marketed in the EU.

Headlines: Alpelisib Nearly Doubles PFS in PIK3-Mutated Breast Cancer
Teaser: A novel PIK3 inhibitor combined with fulvestrant nearly doubled progression- free survival (PFS) in PIK3CA-mutated breast cancer.

Headlines: Worse Prostate Cancer Outcomes With 5-Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors
Teaser: Treatment with 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (5-ARIs) is associated with shorter time to diagnosis and worse mortality in prostate cancer, according to findings from Veterans Affairs electronic health records.

Headlines: Radiation Therapy Consent Forms Too Difficult to Read
Teaser: Cancer patients usually get written consent forms to sign before radiation that are supposed to clearly spell out the treatment risks, but a new U.S. study suggests these forms are too complex for most patients to easily understand.
